docs.snippet: Venezuela was awarded a $1.4 billion credit from the International Monetary Fund yesterday, a distinction that also serves as a seal of approval on the country's economic reform package.         Venezuela's plans to create an open, market-oriented...
docs.lead_paragraph: Venezuela was awarded a $1.4 billion credit from the International Monetary Fund yesterday, a distinction that also serves as a seal of approval on the country's economic reform package. Venezuela's plans to create an open, market-oriented economy, free of the stifling controls and regulations that once characterized virtually all the countries of Latin America, were introduced there in April by the Government of President Rafael Caldera.

headline.main: Venezuela Gets Big I.M.F. Credit, Backing Market Reforms

docs.snippet: At the urging of Defense Secretary William J. Perry, the Clinton Administration is considering easing a decades-old ban on sales of high-technology weapons like advanced fighter jets to Latin America, raising fears of a new arms race in a region that...
docs.lead_paragraph: At the urging of Defense Secretary William J. Perry, the Clinton Administration is considering easing a decades-old ban on sales of high-technology weapons like advanced fighter jets to Latin America, raising fears of a new arms race in a region that has been relatively calm after years of military conflict and dictatorship. Mr. Perry and major weapons makers contend that the blanket restrictions, imposed in the 1970's, are no longer warranted because democracy has spread to every country in the region except Cuba.

headline.main: U.S. Weighs Lifting Curb on Arms Sales to Latin America

docs.snippet: Argentina clinched a place in the final for the first time in 68 years as Hernan Crespo scored both goals in a 2-0 semifinal victory over Portugal in Athens, Ga. It will be Argentina's first trip to the final since 1928, in Amsterdam, where they lost...
docs.lead_paragraph: Argentina clinched a place in the final for the first time in 68 years as Hernan Crespo scored both goals in a 2-0 semifinal victory over Portugal in Athens, Ga. It will be Argentina's first trip to the final since 1928, in Amsterdam, where they lost to Uruguay. Argentina will meet either Brazil or Nigeria in Saturday's final. The second semifinal is today, and Portugal will play the loser Friday for the bronze medal. (Reuters)

headline.main: Argentina Defeats Portugal to Reach Final

docs.snippet: WITH air safety uppermost on travelers' minds, the head of one of the world's biggest travel management organizations is questioning the way in which the Federal Aviation Administration assesses the safety of aviation around the world. Because he...
docs.lead_paragraph: WITH air safety uppermost on travelers' minds, the head of one of the world's biggest travel management organizations is questioning the way in which the Federal Aviation Administration assesses the safety of aviation around the world. Because he finds that assessment lacking, Ivan Michael Schaeffer, the chief executive of Woodside Travel Trust, believes that the agency sometimes unfairly penalizes foreign airlines and has the potential to put at risk passengers on all airlines, including those from the United States who fly to and from a number of foreign countries. The F.A.A., in response, defended the assessment program as an important part of promoting air safety.

headline.main: Business Travel;An industry executive questions the F.A.A.'s assessment of aviation safety around the world.

docs.snippet: Hernan Siles Zuazo, the former President of Bolivia who was one of the chief engineers in moving the country toward political freedom, died on Tuesday night at a hospital in Montevideo, Uruguay, where he lived in retirement. He was 83.     The cause...
docs.lead_paragraph: Hernan Siles Zuazo, the former President of Bolivia who was one of the chief engineers in moving the country toward political freedom, died on Tuesday night at a hospital in Montevideo, Uruguay, where he lived in retirement. He was 83. The cause was an embolism in the lungs after a long illness, Guillermo Richter, Bolivia's Minister of Information, said yesterday.
docs.abstract: Hernan Siles Zuazo, former Bolivian president, dies at age 83; photo (M)

headline.main: Hernan Siles Zuazo, Ex-President of Bolivia, Is Dead at 83

docs.snippet: BY THE time Tab Ramos was in high school, at St. Benedict's Prep in Newark, he was a popular, friendly student. Yet he rarely went out partying, never had to be given a curfew, and always did his schoolwork.    It's not that he was a nerd. It's just...
docs.lead_paragraph: BY THE time Tab Ramos was in high school, at St. Benedict's Prep in Newark, he was a popular, friendly student. Yet he rarely went out partying, never had to be given a curfew, and always did his schoolwork. It's not that he was a nerd. It's just that he was resolute about not risking anything that could thwart his greatest love: playing soccer.
docs.abstract: Biographical profile of Tab Ramos, soccer player for New York/New Jersey MetroStars in new pro league, Major League Soccer; photos; list of New Jersey players on roster of MetroStars (M)è

headline.main: Doing a Star Turn for the Home Team, at Last

docs.snippet: The Chrysler Corporation will announce today that it plans to build a Dakota pickup truck factory in Brazil, according to a person familiar with the plans.    Analysts estimate that such an assembly plant, which will use parts made elsewhere, would...
docs.lead_paragraph: The Chrysler Corporation will announce today that it plans to build a Dakota pickup truck factory in Brazil, according to a person familiar with the plans. Analysts estimate that such an assembly plant, which will use parts made elsewhere, would cost $100 million to $400 million. The trucks will be sold mainly in Brazil, Argentina, Paraguay and Uruguay.
docs.abstract: Chrysler Corp says it will build Dakota pickup truck factory in Brazil; analysts estimate such an assembly plant, which will use parts made elsewhere, would cost $100 million to $400 million; trucks will be sold mainly in Brazil, Argentina, Paraguay and Uruguay (S)

docs.snippet: On Nov. 22, 1994, just after the election that turned Congress over to the Republicans, Senator Christopher J. Dodd was in his office working the phones, campaigning for minority leader. He had one eye on the television when he heard a report that...
docs.lead_paragraph: On Nov. 22, 1994, just after the election that turned Congress over to the Republicans, Senator Christopher J. Dodd was in his office working the phones, campaigning for minority leader. He had one eye on the television when he heard a report that Senator Jesse Helms had warned the President not to visit North Carolina without a bodyguard. Any minute, Mr. Dodd thought, one of his colleagues would surely answer what he considered an especially insensitive affront on the anniversary of the Kennedy assassination.
docs.abstract: Biographical portrait of Sen Christopher Dodd, general chairman of Democratic National Committee, who is being given partial credit for reviving party that was left for dead following Nov '94 elections; photo (M)

headline.main: As Party's Leader, Dodd Hews the Line but With a Credible Touch

docs.snippet: Two major trading blocs in Latin America will seek to join forces in a free-trade agreement, Foreign Minister Miguel Angel Burelli Rivas of Venezuela said today.     In Cochabamba, where the Rio Group of Latin American nations will hold its 10th...
docs.lead_paragraph: Two major trading blocs in Latin America will seek to join forces in a free-trade agreement, Foreign Minister Miguel Angel Burelli Rivas of Venezuela said today. In Cochabamba, where the Rio Group of Latin American nations will hold its 10th presidential summit this week, Mr. Burelli said that the Andean Group and the Mercosur customs union were in talks to create a free-trade zone.
docs.abstract: Two major trading blocs in Latin America, Andean Group and Mercosur customs union, will seek to join forces in free-trade agreement; Andean Group includes Venezuela, Colombia, Peru, Ecuador and Bolivia; Mercosur members are Brazil, Argentina, Paraguay and Uruguay; they will all meet in Cochabamba, Bolivia, where Rio Group of Latin American nations will hold its 10th presidential summit this week (S)

headline.main: Accord Is Sought by 2 Latin Trade Blocs
